edu_storybook.core.filepath module¶

filepath.py

Fix for Python’s inane doubly relative file pathing. So, I give up. Here it is on its own.

edu_storybook.core.filepath.fix_filepath(filepath: str, file: str) → str¶

When referencing a file from a Python file that is not the original start of the Python program, a filepath must be corrected from the current file’s __file__ path, as to start using the current Python file as a based for relative file referencing.

Example:

a.py module_b/

__init__.py c.py config.txt

If a.py imports module_b.c, and if c.py imports c.config as “./config.txt”, it will fail since the Python interpreter pathing is relative to the start script, a.py.

You would call this function as

fix_filepath(__file__, ‘relative/file/path.txt’)

Parameters

  • filepath – The current file context, __file__.

  • file – Relative file to reference.

edu_storybook.core.helper module¶

edu_storybook.core.reg_exps module¶

reg_exps.py

Contains all the regular expressions used in the app.

edu_storybook.core.remove_watchdog module¶

remove_watchdog.py

Simple script for managing the removal of temporary files in a separate process.

Functions:

remove_watchdog(…) future_del_temp(…) - The function you use to mark a file for deletion.

edu_storybook.core.remove_watchdog.future_del_temp(filepath: str = '', files: list = []) → None¶

Marks the temporary files that should be removed later by the Remove Watchdog in the future.

NOTE: Only filepath or files args should be valued, not both (XOR).

Parameters

  • filepath (str) – The path to a file that should be removed.

  • files (str) – A list of files that should be removed.

Returns

None.

edu_storybook.core.remove_watchdog.remove_watchdog(remove_queue)¶

Removes files that are passed into the queue, after a timeout. The format of the remove queue is a list of dicts, with each dict containing “expiration” and “filepath”. It looks like

[
{

“expiration”: 129941234, “filepath”: “temp/somefile.csv”

]

Where “expiration” is epoch time of file to be deleted.
